segments.text: I anticipate that there will be hardly any black oil industry in the United States.
Currently, we're at a level of about 6 million barrels a day.
Forty years from now, I would anticipate we'll be below a million barrels of black oil per day.
Gas production, currently we're running about 17 trillion cubic feet a year.
I would not be surprised 40 years from now,
that we may still be at 14, 15 trillion cubic feet a year.
We do have a pretty fair gas reserve that's left unexplored.
But black oil, we're essentially out of black oil reserves.
People say that you can't deplete oil.
You need to go to Ukraine.
Ukraine at one time was producing 3 million barrels of oil a day back in the 40s.
They're probably producing less than 300,000 barrels a day.
and there's essentially no place to drill.
It's just an area that was drilled over.
Romania is the same thing.
Romania was a huge producer in the 2030s and 40s, and they're essentially depleted.
So barring the development of cold fusion or nuclear fusion, the oil industry is going to be around producing energy.
They're going to be around producing energy, predominantly gas.
Gas production in 19...
94, 95, wellhead value will exceed the value of oil production for the first time.
And it will continue to be a bigger and bigger share.
And where are the gas reserves in the rest of the world?
I mean, outside of the United States?
Outside of the U.S. Part of the greatest gas reserves that are known are in Russia.
There's tremendous gas reserves.
The United States probably has 160 trillion
feet of gas, of proven gas reserves.
Russia probably has at least 10 times that amount that there have been discovery wells drilled in.
They have not developed them because they don't have the pipeline outlets for it.
Indonesia has tremendous gas reserves, wells that are capable of producing 100 billion feet a day.
Average well in the United States produces less than half a million feet.
Indonesia, as well, is capable of producing 200 times what our average will.
The problem is that there's no population centers that can utilize that much gas.
Saudi Arabia has a tremendous amount of gas.
Libya has a lot of gas.
But, of course, to liquefy this is very expensive.
It runs $5, $6 an MCF to liquefy natural gas and use it.
And it's just not competitive with fuel oil at this time.
So it has to, the supply, the production needs to be near the end users.
Yes, right.
Now Russia is close enough to Europe that eventually, probably in the next 10 years, there will be major pipeline construction.
You need something on the order of probably $5 billion worth of pipeline construction
to get Russian gas into Europe.
Now, there are some pipelines in there now, but they're not in there.
Where does Western, or even Eastern Europe, stand in energy for the future?
Eastern Europe is pretty energy deficient.
I mean, they import a lot out of the, of course, the Dutch North Sea.
British North Sea has brought in a lot.
Norway.
And a lot comes from Russia.
But the Russian, of course, imports are declining now.
But there's a good bit of energy over there.
And of course, they're not very far away from Saudi either.
You can bring in Saudi crude easily.
So is it that they don't have it in the ground, or are they like the Soviets and not able to get it out?
They just simply don't have it.
Romania has had old, old fields that are essentially depleted.
There's not very much prospect in Poland, virtually none in Italy.
Spain has very poor prospects.
Some in the Paris Basin in France, but not big reserves.
A little bit in Germany, but there's really not a lot of onshore production in Europe.
How will the rules of our industry change?
How will the rules of the game change with changing environmental standards?
Well, the industry is really a lot further developed environmentally than most people, particularly outside the industry, think.
There was a lot of excesses, a lot of damage to environmental situations in the 30s.
Wells blew out.
They let them blow out, catch on fire.
We ran oil down the creeks, flared gas, ran salt water on the ground.
The commissions began tightening the rules, the state commissions, oil and gas commissions, railroad commission, began tightening the rules in the early 50s.
By the early 60s, they were enforcing these rules.
They were requiring cement jobs be inspected.
They reduced all saltwater disposal out on the ground.
carefully control the completion of wells.
I would say by the early 70s, the environmental controls in the petroleum industry were strictly in place.
Now, some of the things that they're talking about today certainly is going to be some problems, but we're a lot further along controlling our environmental problems than people realize that we are.
And we started a long time ago, long before it became fashionable to talk about
So you don't think that that's going to continue to change our costs, our ability to survive?
I think it'll have some impact on it, and of course they always talk about some scary things, but generally we don't see it as a major problem.
We routinely police our locations, looking for any type of spills and this type of thing.
We try to run clean operations, and I think most people do.
Can you give me an example or two about
How strict the regulations that we operate are under are?
Well, we ran about two barrels of salt water inadvertently in a creek in West Virginia when we were operating there in 1979.
And they put our superintendent in jail.
So not that we didn't intend to do it, but they certainly had our attention a long time ago.
And this was not very salty water either.
They're quite strictly enforced.

For example, if you go to cement a well today, you have to file a permit long in advance, you have to notify the Railroad Commission where the water sands are, you've got to run pipe through all those sands, you've got to cement very carefully, and in all probability there will be an inspector on location to see that you cemented it properly.
When you go to plug wells, there are very strict plugging requirements that we didn't have 30 years ago.
But I think most of the environmental requirements are pretty well in place.
Looking at the numbers for 1993, it shows that we have 575,000 wells.
That's oil wells, I believe.
You're right, that's oil wells.
The total wells are 865,000.

If we have to be very careful about the way we plug wells, and if we're getting less and less money from each well that we have to plug, are we going to have enough money to plug adequately all the wells that we have?
Well, to be an operator in any state, when you drill a well or you take over a well, you're required to be bonded.
You're required to have the money.
You either put it up in cash or put up a bond to plug that well.
Now, I guess there are some wells that go through bankruptcy and some things like that, that there may be some loopholes in it.
But I would say that an extremely high percentage of the wells, the plugging costs are already in place.
The largest oil field in Alabama is the Citronella unit.
I've been the engineering manager there for many years.
We have an escrow fund that within another three years, the field will last another 10 or 15 years.
then three more years we will have enough cash on hand to plug all of our wells at the time that's required to plug them.
So we're looking ahead to our plugging requirements.
Do you have any other, back to policy, domestic policy, have there been any big domestic policy dodges or anything that they could have done better?
The petroleum industry is so divided that there's really no clear action that is recommended from the industry that would help them.
There's talks of tax breaks.
There's talks of lesser royalties on offshore production.
There's discussion of opening up federal lands that have been put off limits for drilling.
Frankly, I think these are all mandates that really are not going to do very much for the industry.

solution that I've ever seen that would have any consequence and it would save stripper production to some extent is if the federal government would put a floor under the import price of oil, say at $20 a barrel.
This would automatically raise the price of oil to $20 a barrel and if they bring it in below that, well then the government just takes the profit out of it.
This is terribly unpopular, and I don't think that there is any political support.
If you've got 100 senators, I doubt you'd get one of them to vote for it.
I don't see any other solution.
I think the other things are simply short-term band-aids for the industry.
I'm trying to look over my notes.
I don't see...

don't see any other any other questions i had is there anything else about the history of the oil and gas the last 30 years that is important that we haven't talked about i think that we've covered certainly the major factors in it we've covered employment the capital expenditure levels we've talked about low supply of oil and gas where we're going some view of where we're going on the international scene i think you've covered
Most of the topics are consequences.
All right.
Thank you very much.
Yes, sir.
